title: The Infidel
descriptions:
The Infidel (2010) is a British comedy about identity, faith, and family, centered on Mahmud Nasir, a middle-aged, easygoing Muslim taxi driver in London. Mahmud lives a fairly secular life: he enjoys pop music, curses a bit too freely, and isn’t especially devout, though he tries to keep up appearances for the sake of his wife, Saamiya, and their son, Rashid. His comfortable world tilts when Rashid becomes engaged to the daughter of a prominent, ultraconservative imam, Arshad El-Masri, whose approval depends on Mahmud projecting spotless religious credibility.

As Mahmud navigates the social pressure to present as the perfect Muslim father-in-law, he discovers a shocking secret while sorting through his recently deceased mother’s belongings: his birth certificate reveals that he was adopted and that his birth name is Solly Shimshillewitz. Mahmud is, in fact, Jewish by birth. This revelation detonates his sense of self. Already prone to bending rules, Mahmud now must confront the possibility that the identity he has worn all his life is more complicated than he imagined, and that the lines he thought separated “us” from “them” are far blurrier.

Compelled to know more about his origins, Mahmud tracks down his biological father, Izzy, an elderly Jewish man who is terminally ill and living in a care home. Izzy wants to see his son, but there’s a problem: Mahmud can only visit if he convincingly presents as Jewish to Izzy’s cranky, protective nurse and to members of the local Jewish community. Desperate, Mahmud reluctantly enlists the help of his sharp-tongued neighbor, Lenny, a lapsed Jewish cabbie with an encyclopedic knowledge of Yiddish slang and cultural quirks. What follows is a crash course in Jewish customs, prayers, and history, played for both humor and heart as Mahmud stumbles through blessings, synagogue etiquette, and Hebrew phrases.

Meanwhile, the pressure from Arshad El-Masri intensifies. The imam’s righteousness and surveillance make Mahmud hide his visits to Izzy and his attempts to learn about Judaism. He becomes trapped in a cycle of lies—pretending to be a model Muslim for Arshad and Saamiya while privately practicing Jewish rituals to gain access to his father. The duplicity spirals into farce: Mahmud’s clothes, music, and speech shift depending on whom he’s with, and he struggles to contain the two worlds from colliding.

As Mahmud grows closer to Izzy and Lenny, he begins to see the common ground between the communities: the rhythms of family life, the shared values, and even the similar cadences of religious humor. Yet his inner turmoil deepens when he learns the truth behind his adoption and the reasons his birth identity was kept hidden. His attempts to tell Saamiya are repeatedly derailed by fear and the looming wedding arrangements, while Rashid, eager to impress Arshad, becomes more rigidly observant, judging his father’s perceived laxity.

The inevitable collision arrives when Mahmud’s secret comes out publicly, threatening Rashid’s engagement and Mahmud’s standing in both communities. Accused of hypocrisy and betrayal, he is ostracized, and Arshad uses the scandal to assert his moral authority. But in the fallout, Mahmud confronts the performative piety around him and owns the fullness of his identity. With unexpected allies—especially Lenny—he exposes hypocrisies and challenges the idea that faith must be policed through strict labels.

In the end, Mahmud reconciles with Saamiya by telling the truth, reaches a fragile but heartfelt resolution with Izzy, and helps Rashid see that character matters more than credentials. The film concludes on a note of inclusive humor, suggesting that identity is as much about love, decency, and lived experience as it is about birth or doctrine. The Infidel uses comedy to push back against sectarianism, celebrating the messy, human middle ground where empathy and self-acceptance can flourish.
